awd_titl_txt: Generalization of Non-Uniform Rational Bezier Splines: Theory and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Computer models today can accurately capture a wide variety shapes, ranging from aerodynamic wings, to automotive components. This versatility stems from a particular modeling technique called non-uniform rational Bezier-splines (i.e., NURBS). Indeed, NURBS are the most popular curve and surface modeling technique today, and is the de facto standard in computer aided design. However, an inherent short-coming of NURBS is its inability to capture sharp discontinuities. This shortcoming reveals itself in several applications including manufacturing planning, failure analysis, fluid flow modeling, etc. This project will address this long-standing deficiency by pursuing a generalization of NURBS, and establishing its effectiveness through targeted applications. The project will have a wide societal impact by allowing engineers to create and simulate much more complex models than possible today. The research team will disseminate the research findings and software to the scientific community. Teaching modules will be created to excite young students about computer modeling, scientific computing, and engineering.  These modules will target K-12 students, including underrepresented minority students.

The project will lead to a novel generalization of NURBS that is obtained by decoupling the basis functions in NURBS along different directions. This simple, yet unexplored, concept can help resolve many of the fundamental challenges in NURBS, specifically, its inability to capture discontinuities. The team will first establish the theoretical foundations of the generalization. Next, using the decoupled weights as extra design variables, new applications in modeling of "as additively manufactured" parts, and iso-geometric analysis, will be pursued. To accelerate dissemination of knowledge, the team will also develop a tool-kit to demonstrate the potential benefits, and highlight possible drawbacks, of the generalization.

por.por_cntn:
Non-uniform Rational Bezier Splines (NURBS) are perhaps one of the most popular curve and surface representations today. They are the de facto standard in computer-aided design. They are also extensively used in iso-geometric analysis, topology optimization, material modeling, etc. However, an inherent shortcoming of NURBS is its inability to capture sharp gradients and discontinuities. This shortcoming reveals itself in each of the above applications.

In this project, a generalization of NURBS was obtained by decoupling the basis functions in different directions. This simple yet unexplored concept resolves many of the fundamental challenges in NURBS. For example, it can capture sharp gradients much more effectively than classic NURBS. Furthermore, this decoupling allows for treating the weights as additional degrees of freedom in a wider range of applications compared to classic NURBS.

Intellectual Merit

It was established that the proposed generalizations can be exactly transformed to equivalent, but higher order, classic NURBS, ensuring a strong theoretical foundation. However, the additional flexibility and increased control can be effectively used for improved approximation of a certain class of surfaces such as helicoids, revolved surfaces, and minimal surfaces. In addition, in iso-geometric analysis, the generalization allows for decoupling of the basis functions in geometry and solution, leading to a novel adaptivity technique where the unknown solution weights also serve as design variables. Consequently, the analytical sensitivities can be derived efficiently, and a more accurate approximation of the field could be obtained. This leads to the optimal rational function space while preserving the underlying geometry as well as its parameterization.

Broader Impact

The PI and graduate student developed a toolkit, using the popular Matlab? environment, to demonstrate the benefits of the generalization. The toolkit was exploited for an accurate representation of curves and surfaces, and, in iso-geometric analysis, for improved approximations of physical fields. This toolkit is freely available from the PI?s research website.
